title: Fighting typeface??
content:
![](http://web.archive.org/web/20081013033538im_/http:/typophile.com/files/timeto9fight_6213.jpg)

Does anyone find it odd they used Bodoni or something similar to title this new book by Senator Jim Webb, former military man, a guy who always looks like he’s chewing bullets?  
To me it sure doesn’t bring up the concept of “fight” - unless it’s a knockdown-dragout in a fashion design house or somewhere similarly elegant.

I would’ve used something aggressive yet dignified. Any suggestions?

 [‹ Do you live in Athens or Barcelona?](http://web.archive.org/web/20081013033538/http:/typophile.com/node/45343 "Go to previous forum topic") [Initial Drop Cap with Slant ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20081013033538/http:/typophile.com/node/45353 "Go to next forum topic")
author: dinazina

comments.content: I dunno. Seems like it would be a good idea to de-emphasize the physical aggression connotations of his Marine Corps background (as ex-Army myself, that’s definitely not a gratuitous swipe at the military), and transfer the idea of ’fight’ to a more intellectual battleground — reasoning together instead of confrontation, that kind of thing.
Gus, I hadn’t thought of that. (But isn’t he Navy?)
Given the buzz about his VP chances, I’m surprised they didn’t use Gotham. Isn’t Optima John McCain’s font? I bet the designer was a Republican. :)

I would have thought Knockout would be the obvious choice. :)

T

Bodoni is one of the popular styles associated with elite American politics; it shows up on all sorts of generic stuff around Washington—which is the mother of all target markets for these kinds of books.

\> But isn’t he Navy?

According to his [Senate bio](http://web.archive.org/web/20081013033538/http:/webb.senate.gov/jim), he graduated from the Naval Academy, but went into the Marines.
